sn35.94:1.2: “Mendicants, these six fields of contact bring suffering when they’re untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.4: The field of eye contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.5: The field of ear contact … nose contact … tongue contact … body contact …
sn35.94:1.6: The field of mind contact brings suffering when it’s untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:1.7: These six fields of contact bring suffering when they’re untamed, unguarded, unprotected, and unrestrained.
sn35.94:2.1: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.3: The field of eye contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.4: The field of ear contact … nose contact … tongue contact … body contact …
sn35.94:2.5: The field of mind contact brings happiness when it’s well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.
sn35.94:2.6: These six fields of contact bring happiness when they’re well tamed, well guarded, well protected, and well restrained.”
sn35.94:2.7: That is what the Buddha said.
sn35.94:2.8: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:
sn35.94:3.1: “Mendicants, it’s just the six fields of contact
sn35.94:3.2: that lead the unrestrained to suffering.
sn35.94:3.3: Those who understand how to restrain them
sn35.94:3.4: live with faith as partner, not festering.
sn35.94:4.3: get rid of all manner of desire for the pleasant,
sn35.94:4.4: without hating what you don’t like.
sn35.94:5.1: When you’ve heard sounds both liked and disliked,
sn35.94:5.2: don’t fall under the thrall of sounds you like,
sn35.94:5.3: get rid of hate for the unliked,
sn35.94:5.4: and don’t hurt your mind <j>by thinking of what you don’t like.
sn35.94:6.1: When you’ve smelled a pleasant, fragrant scent,
sn35.94:6.2: and one that’s foul and unpleasant,
sn35.94:6.3: get rid of repulsion for the unpleasant,
sn35.94:6.4: while not yielding to desire for the pleasant.
sn35.94:7.1: When you’ve enjoyed a sweet, delicious taste,
sn35.94:7.2: and sometimes those that are bitter,
sn35.94:7.3: don’t be attached to enjoying sweet tastes,
sn35.94:8.1: Don’t be intoxicated by a pleasant touch,
sn35.94:8.2: and don’t tremble at a painful touch.
sn35.94:8.3: Look with equanimity at the duality <j>of pleasant and painful contacts,
sn35.94:9.1: People generally let their perceptions proliferate;
sn35.94:9.2: perceiving and proliferating, they are attracted.
sn35.94:9.3: When you’ve cast aside all thoughts of domestic life,
sn35.94:10.1: When the mind is well developed like this <j>regarding the six,
sn35.94:10.2: it doesn’t waver at contacts at all.
sn35.94:10.3: Mendicants, those who have mastered greed and hate
